column1: A four-hour Sprint Planning is the timebox for Sprints that are ... long.
Explanation: Sprint Planning is 8 hours for a one-month Sprint and usually shorter proportionally for short Sprints.

column1: Which of the following does NOT happen in the first Sprint? (Choose 2 answers)
Answer Option 2: Creating a piece of working software
Explanation:
The Product Backlog is a dynamic concept that is never complete; especially, at the beginning of the project. Trying to prepare a complete Product Backlog at the beginning of the project is a form of upfront planning that doesn't suit Agile environments. The same goes for the architecture; it's not designed upfront, because we don't know exactly what we're going to develop.

All Sprints have the same purpose of bringing value to the customer by creating a potentially releasable Increment.

column1: Which of the following is a responsibility of the project manager in Scrum?
Answer Option 1: There's no project manager in Scrum
Answer Option 5: Preparing the project plan and Gantt Charts
Explanation: There are only three roles in Scrum and it's not allowed to add other roles or titles: Product Owner, Scrum Master and Development Team

column1: Using timeboxed Sprints help limit work-in-progress.
Explanation:
When working inside timeboxes, it's better to limit work-in-progress and get items done before going to the next ones; otherwise, chances would be high that the team ends up with many in-progress items and not enough "Done" items at the end of the Sprint.
Limiting work-in-progress is a lean concept that avoids waste.

column1: Who makes sure that all developers are doing their tasks during the Sprint?
Explanation:
The developers take responsibility for doing the tasks (assignment) themselves and the Development Team ensures that all tasks are done properly. Remember that they are self-organized.

When items are "Done", the Product Owner checks them but this is focused on the item rather than individuals; all developers are accountable for their outputs.

column1: Which is NOT a Development Team responsibility?
Answer Option 4: Breaking down the items in the Product Backlog into smaller items
Explanation: This is the responsibility of the Product Owner to break down the large Product Backlog items into smaller ones. The Development Team usually "helps" in this but it doesn't make them responsible.

column1: Which two statements are correct during the Sprint?
Answer Option 1: Some Sprint Backlog items would be replaced with items from the Product Backlog if the priorities change
Answer Option 2: The scope may be clarified as more is learned
Answer Option 3: The scope may be re-negotiated as more is learned
Answer Option 4: Some Sprint Backlog items would be moved back to the Product Backlog to be completed in future Sprints
Explanation: During the Sprint, the Product Backlog items in the Sprint Backlog would not be added or removed but as more is learned, the scope may be clarified and re-negotiated between the Product Owner and Development Team. This is mainly focused on the interpretation of the Product Backlog items and the tasks created by decomposing them.

column1: Which of the following are optional in Scrum? (choose 2 answers)
Explanation:
Having a release plan is usually required but it's not part of the framework and is not mandatory.
Velocity calculation is also helpful and recommended but is not part of the framework.
The rest are Scrum artifacts. All Scrum roles, events and artifacts are mandatory.

column1: Which of the following is a right action from the Scrum Master in response to a Product Owner who has problems managing the Product Backlog?
Answer Option 1: Ask the Development Team to help the Product Owner understand the dependencies among items to be used in ordering them
Answer Option 2: Help the Product Owner order the items
Answer Option 3: Extend the Sprint so that the Product Owner has more time ordering items
Answer Option 4: Ask the customer to order the items instead of the Product Owner
Explanation: The Scrum Master is supposed to know the tools and techniques and to help everyone in that regard. However, it's only about helping, training, coaching and consulting rather than taking over.

column1: The Product Owner ensures enough items are selected from the Product Backlog in the Sprint Planning meeting to satisfy the stakeholders.
Explanation: It's only up to the developers to decide how many items they will select from the top of the Product Backlog. The Product Owner only orders the items.

column1: All of the following are inputs to the Sprint Planning meeting, EXCEPT:
Explanation: The Sprint Goal is created during the Sprint Planning. The rest are the existing information we use for planning the Sprint.

column1: What's the maximum duration of Sprint Planning when the Product Backlog is not clear?
Explanation:
The maximum duration of Sprint Planning for a one month Sprint (which is the longest allowed Sprint) is 8 hours.
This is not dependent on any other factor such as the state of the Product Backlog.

column1: There are 6 teams working on the same product. How many Product Owners do they need?
Answer Option 4: Depends on the complexity of the product
Explanation: One project for one product has only one Product Backlog and one Product Owner. Otherwise, prioritization and accountability would be too difficult.

column1: How is management external to the Scrum team involved in the Daily Scrum?
Answer Option 1: The Product Owner represents their opinions
Answer Option 4: Management can be present at the meeting and open it with their updates or opinions
Explanation: The Daily Scrum is only for the Development Team. Others can attend but they won't participate.

column1: What should the Product Owner do during the Sprint Retrospective?
Answer Option 2: Participate as a Scrum Team member
Answer Option 3: Prioritize the outputs of the meeting
Answer Option 4: Summarize and report the results to the senior management
Explanation: The whole Scrum Team should participate in the Sprint Retrospective to find an improvement to be applied in the next Sprint; including the Product Owner.

column1: What's the main responsibility of testers?
Answer Option 3: Help the team incorporate the test driven development practice
Answer Option 5: There's no tester role in Scrum
Explanation:
There are only three roles in Scrum: Product Owner, Scrum Master and Development Team. It's not allowed to define new roles and the Development Team members should not have any titles; they are all "developers". It is so, because we want all of them to be accountable for everything and to collaborate with each other.
Each person has his/her own area of expertise, such as testing, and that person will be more focused on testing tasks but it doesn't mean that we can call the person "tester".

column1: It is OK for the items at the bottom of the Product Backlog to have less detail compared to those that the top.
Explanation: Items on the bottom of the Product Backlog won't be developed soon, therefore, we don't need to spend too much time on them. Otherwise, it would be a form of upfront planning.

column1: Product Backlog refinement is the act of ... to the items in the Product Backlog.
Explanation:
Product Backlog refinement is defined in the Scrum Guide as the act of adding detail, estimates and order to the Product Backlog items.

Remember that Product Backlog refinement is an ongoing activity and is not timeboxed. The rule is that it shouldn't take more than 10% of the developers' time.

column1: Who should know the most about the project performance?
Explanation: Measuring the release or project performance is the Product Owner's responsibility. Measuring the Sprint performance is the Development Team's responsibility.

column1: It's better to have longer Sprints when the project is riskier.
Explanation: When Sprints are shorter, there are more opportunities for demonstration, receiving feedback and adaptation. So, when risks are higher, it's better to have shorter Sprints (if possible).

column1: If the customer wants a new feature to be added to the current Sprint, how should the Development Team respond?
Answer Option 1: Ask the Product Owner to work with the customer
Answer Option 2: Add the item to the bottom of the Sprint Backlog
Answer Option 4: Add the item to the Product Backlog
Answer Option 5: Swap the item with one of the items in the Sprint Backlog
Explanation: Such a request would be rejected because we don't add or remove the items in the Sprint Backlog (while we always add and remove tasks). However, this is up to the Product Owner to reject this request, rather than the developers. So, they should just refer the customer to the Product Owner. In very special cases, the new feature might be so special and the project environment so influenced that the introduction of the new feature makes the current Sprint Goal invalid and therefore the Product Owner will cancel the Sprint. Remember, this doesn't happen often.

column1: The Development Team is free to change its engineering practices whenever they want.
Explanation:
The Development Team is self-organized and cross-functional; they have to decide how best to handle their development and this decision can evolve during the project as more is learned about the needs.

This is about their development and doesn't have to be constrained by the Sprints. The elements that shouldn't be changed during the Sprint are those required for keeping them focused on their development.

column1: An organization has decided to adopt Scrum. What happens if they tailor the Scrum terminology to match their current environment? (Choose 3 answers)
Answer Option 1: Management may feel less enthusiastic about the change
Answer Option 2: The change might not be obvious to everyone and some benefits may be lost
Answer Option 3: They will get better results adopting Scrum this way
Answer Option 4: The change might not be obvious to everyone and therefore very little change actually happen
Explanation: Scrum is a framework rather than a methodology. It's very lightweight and only contains the essential required aspects. Therefore, it shouldn't be tailored like methodologies (eg PRINCE2).

column1: The Product Owner can transfer some of his/her accountability to the developers.
Explanation: The Product Owner can delegate his/her responsibilities to the development team but he/she stays accountable.

column1: When should the Product Backlog items be refined? (Choose 2 answers)
Answer Option 1: In one or two preceding Sprints
Answer Option 2: In the time between the two Sprints
Answer Option 3: During the Sprint, if they have not been refined in the previous Sprints
Explanation:
Product Backlog refinement is a continuous activity. When an item is at the top of the backlog, which means it will be developed in the near future, more refinements are usually needed to make sure it is clear and contains just enough details (not all possible details).
It's preferred to have the items that will be selected in the Sprint Backlog completely refined before Sprint Planning; however, it's OK to have more refinement done during the development.
Remember that there's no such thing as Sprint 0 and there's no time between two Sprints that can be spent on something such as refinement. The team is also cross-functional and does the a-z of the work needed for each item, including refinement; they don't use people from other parts of the company.

column1: Which role is the equivalent of project manager in Scrum?
Explanation: The project management activities are distributed among all three roles.

column1: What are the benefits of having tests in the definition of "Done"? (Choose 3 answers)
Answer Option 2: Increments would be closer to being potentially shippable
Answer Option 4: Reporting would be easier for the project manager
Explanation:
Items are not really done unless we have tested them; so, tests should be included in the definition of "Done". In this case, the Increments will be closer to what we can practically call "complete", "done", "potentially releasable", or "potentially shippable"; to something useable for the users.

Increments should be potentially releasable; for starters, because it makes it easier for the customer to try it and give feedback. The feedback enables adaptation, which is essential to Agile.

Having an effective definition of "Done" increases transparency because everyone will know what we mean when we say an items is done.

column1: What's the vertical axis in a typical burn-down chart?
Explanation: The horizontal axis is time, the vertical axis is the remaining amount of work and the trend line shows the forecasted finish date if the Product Backlog and the team capacity stay the same.

column1: Which statement can be considered an Increment?
Answer Option 1: A few new features in a usable state that are added to those delivered in the previous Sprints
Answer Option 2: A user interface layout design for the software
Answer Option 3: A UML diagram that describes the functionalities in the future Sprints
Answer Option 4: A decomposition of Product Backlog items into tasks that will be used in the future Sprints
Explanation:
Increments are a set of done Product Backlog items. All items should be non-technical and independent.
The user interface design evolves throughout the project, as with the database architecture and other similar things. They are all part of functional features rather than separate ones.

column1: How should a Product Backlog item be refined when it is located at the top? (Choose 2 answers)
Answer Option 1: All the tasks required for completing it should be identified
Answer Option 2: In a way that it can be "Done" in the timeboxed duration of one Sprint
Answer Option 3: In a way that it's clear enough for the developers
Answer Option 4: It should be clear which developer is responsible for it
Explanation:
Items at the top of the Product Backlog should be small enough to fit in one Sprint. They should also be clear and detailed enough; but not too detailed (eg not with all tasks need to be identified) as it would be upfront planning. Tasks are created gradually during the Sprint.
Product Backlog items require multiple expertise and usually done by multiple developers. Therefore, they are not assigned. Tasks, however, are assigned to the individual developers, while everyone stays accountable.

column1: Which of the following are ways for the stakeholders to interact with the Development Team? (Choose 2 answers)
Explanation: We don't want the team to be distracted; they need to stay focused and productive. That's why their direct interactions with the customer is limited to the Sprint Review or via the Product Owner.

column1: When's a new Increment of working software must be available?
Answer Option 2: When the Product Owner asks for it
Answer Option 3: At the end of each Sprint
Answer Option 5: Whenever the user acceptance testing is done
Explanation: An Increment of "Done" working software, which is potentially releasable, must be produced at the end of each Sprint.

column1: Which Scrum event is for process improvement?
Explanation: We value individuals and interactions over processes and tools but it doesn't mean that we ignore the need for processes. Scrum provides a process (way of working) which should be continuously improved by Sprint Retrospective and in other opportunities.

column1: There should be frequent integration Sprints to integrate the solution.
Explanation: There's no integration Sprint in Scrum. All Sprints are the same and create increments. Integration is done during all Sprints.

column1: The Product Owner is responsible for both maximizing the value of the product and the value of the work of the Development Team.
Explanation: The value of the work of the team is nothing but the value they create through the product. This is how the section on Product Owner is opened in the Scrum Guide: The Product Owner is responsible for maximizing the value of the product and the work of the Development Team. How this is done may vary widely across organizations, Scrum Teams and individuals.

column1: When is a Sprint Backlog item considered complete?
Answer Option 1: When all of its tasks are complete
Answer Option 3: When everything is done based on the definition of "Done"
Answer Option 4: When the user acceptance tests are done
Explanation:
When the item is complete based on the definition of "Done", the end users can use it and it creates an Increment of working software which is potentially releasable.

Note: if all the tasks for an item are complete, it doesn't necessarily mean that the item is complete because we might have forgotten to add some of the tasks.

column1: Which statement best describes the Sprint Backlog?
Answer Option 1: Each of its items has been estimated in hours
Answer Option 2: It's the Development Team's plan for the Sprint
Answer Option 3: It's composed by the Product Owner
Answer Option 4: Each of its items are assigned to a team member
Explanation:
The Sprint Backlog is created during the Sprint Planning and includes the items selected from the Product Backlog (by the Development Team) and the tasks created by decomposing the items (by the Development Team).
Developers keep adding tasks during the Sprint, so the Sprint Backlog updates. It's the Development Team's plan for the current Sprint. This plan is not detailed upfront.
If the Development Team cannot deliver some of the items, they will go back to the Product Backlog and will be ordered again; they do not go to the next Sprint automatically.
Each task is assigned to one developer or a pair of developers but the ownership is still shared. Items are not assigned or owned by specific developers, all of them share accountability.

column1: When is a Sprint cancelled?
Answer Option 1: When a key developer cannot work for awhile
Answer Option 2: When the Sprint Goal doesn't make sense anymore
Answer Option 3: When all Sprint Backlog items won't be finished until the end of the Sprint
Answer Option 4: When the definition of "Done" is met
Explanation: Sprints are cancelled by the Product Owner only because they don't make sense anymore or become obsolete. It's mainly about the Sprint Goal.

column1: Which of the following is not a role in Scrum?
Explanation: There are only three roles in Scrum: Scrum Master, Product Owner and Development Team. Other roles or titles are not recognized.

column1: The Scrum Master is a management role.
Explanation: The Scrum Master is a management role but for the process rather than for the people.

column1: Which of the following is the LEAST productive way for the Scrum Master to improve the Development Team's communications with the Product Owner?
Answer Option 1: Act as a go-between for them
Answer Option 2: Teach them how to effectively communicate
Answer Option 4: Suggest effective communication tools and techniques to the Product Owner
Explanation: Acting as a go-between weakens the team and blocks their self-organization. The Scrum Master is supposed to teach and coach.

column1: Each Development Team member should be cross-functional.
Explanation:
The Development Team as a whole is cross-functional, which means the sum of all developers with their different expertise. It doesn't mean that we need to have cross-functional individuals or "Development Team members".
Each individual is an expert in one or more technical layer or aspect of the project and the team they create is cross-functional (having all the expertise required to get the job done, without any need for external resources).

column1: Who supports the Scrum Master in removing impediments? (Choose 2 answers)
Explanation: The Development Team can help the Scrum Master because of their understanding of how the work is done. Some impediments are rooted in external causes and that's why the Scrum Master might need to have the senior management's support in removing them.

column1: Why is Daily Scrum at the same time and same place?
Answer Option 1: Because the place can be named
Answer Option 2: Because the Product Owner requires it
Answer Option 3: To reduce complexity and increase simplicity
Answer Option 4: To make it easier to book the rooms
Explanation:
It's not wise to spend some time everyday scheduling the next Daily Scrum when the meeting itself is only 15 minutes.
We usually expect to have a common place for the team and have them collocated. The meeting will be held in the same common place (ie in front of the Scrum board); we don't book a meeting room for it.

column1: When should Increments be shipped?
Answer Option 1: When the Increment is free of defects
Explanation: All Increments should be potentially releasable (shippable) but we don't have to release all of them. It depends on the project environment and the customer and the Product Owner is supposed to decide on it.

column1: The Product Owner should use burn-down charts to track progress.
Explanation: Burn-down charts are very common for tracking and representing progress but they are not mandatory and the Product Owner can use other tools/techniques as well.

column1: Which statements are correct about a Sprint Backlog item that was not finished by the end of the Sprint? (Choose 2 answers)
Answer Option 1: It will be moved back to the Product Backlog
Answer Option 2: It won't be demonstrated at the Sprint Review meeting
Answer Option 3: The Sprint will be extended until the item is done
Answer Option 4: It will be demonstrated to the stakeholders but pointed out that it's not complete yet
Answer Option 5: It will be completed in the next Sprint
Explanation: Only the 100% complete items are demonstrated to avoid confusion. When something is not complete, it will be moved back to the Product Backlog. If it's still on the top of the Product Backlog, development will continue in the next Sprint.

column1: The Product Owner does not have to be one person and the role can be played by a committee.
Explanation:
It's possible to have a committee responsible for product ownership but on a representative of that committee would be called the Product Owner.

There's always one Product Owner for a product, even if there are multiple teams.

column1: What are the common outcomes of Daily Scrums? (Choose 2 answers)
Answer Option 1: Everyone is clear on the next steps towards the Sprint Goal
Answer Option 2: The Product Owner is informed of the progress
Answer Option 3: The impediments are discussed and possible solutions selected
Answer Option 4: The Scrum Master identifies new impediments
Explanation:
Impediments are pointed out in the Daily Scrum but we don't discuss them.

Each developer informs everyone about the tasks they will handle in the next 24 hours, which is how the team is progressing towards the goal.

column1: Self-organizing teams are characterized by their ability to ...
Answer Option 2: Decide on which features will be added to the product
Explanation: The Development Team is focused on creating Increments during Sprints and are self-organized to find out how to best accomplish it. Higher-level decisions for the project are done by the Product Owner and other stakeholders.

column1: Which of the following is a responsibility of team leaders when multiple teams are working on the same product?
Answer Option 1: Acting as middle men between the Product Owner and the developers
Answer Option 2: There's no team leaders in Scrum
Answer Option 3: Help the Product Owner with release planning
Explanation: There are only three roles in Scrum and other roles or titles are not recognized: Product Owner, Scrum Master, Development Team

column1: What should the Product Owner do during Sprint zero?
Answer Option 1: Prepare the Product Backlog for the next few Sprints
Answer Option 2: Communicate with the customer and understand the requirements
Answer Option 3: There's no such thing as Sprint zero
Answer Option 4: Prepare the Product Backlog for the whole project
Explanation: There's no such thing as Sprint zero. The first Sprint is called Sprint 1 and it's exactly the same as other Sprints: creates an Increment. The infrastructure, tools and requirements are prepared gradually throughout the project.

column1: Which three of the following are responsibilities of a self-organizing team?
Answer Option 1: Create tasks for Sprint Backlog items
Answer Option 2: Estimate the amount of work of the newly created Product Backlog items
Answer Option 3: Pull Product Backlog items for the upcoming Sprint
Explanation:
It's the responsibility of the Development Team to estimate the amount of work of Product Backlog items and to select appropriate number of them for each Sprint. They also break down the items into tasks during the Sprint.

Measuring the project performance is the responsibility of the Product Owner, while measuring the Sprint performance is done by the Development Team.

Creating new Product Backlog items, ordering them (prioritization) and making sure that everyone has a clear understanding of them is the responsibility of the Product Owner.

column1: The end users are the most important stakeholders for the Product Owner.
Explanation: Considering the end users as the most important stakeholders helps increase value.

column1: How much of the Sprint Backlog should be defined during the Sprint Planning meeting?
Answer Option 1: Just enough, so the Development Team can forecast what it can do and to start the first several days of the Sprint.
Answer Option 2: Just enough for the Scrum Master to be able to assign tasks to developers.
Answer Option 3: Just enough to understand design and architecture.
Explanation:
The Sprint Backlog includes the items selected from the Product Backlog and the tasks created by decomposing the items.

The items are completely planned in the Sprint Planning but not all tasks are created; just enough for the first few days of development. The rest of the tasks will be created during the Sprint.

column1: Who's responsible for Gantt Charts in Scrum?
Explanation: Gantt Chart is not a Scrum artifact and not compatible with the framework.

column1: Which statements are correct about Product Backlog refinement? (Choose 2 answers)
Answer Option 1: It should be done right before the Sprint Planning
Answer Option 2: The Scrum Master should facilitate it
Answer Option 3: It shouldn't take more than 10% of the Development Team's time
Explanation:
If multiple teams are working on the project, they will participate in the refinement as well. Refinement can take any amount of time from the Product Owner but not more than 10% of the capacity of the Development Team.

Refinement is a continuous activity not limited to a certain time during the Sprint. The Scrum Master only facilitates the meetings as requested or required; not by default.

column1: The Product Owner has doubts about the quality of the definition of "Done". What should s/he do?
Answer Option 2: Adjust the definition of "Done" at the end of the Sprint
Answer Option 3: Ask the company QA department to investigate the issue
Answer Option 4: Point it out in the next Sprint Retrospective
Explanation: The Development Team is responsible for the definition of "Done" rather than the Product Owner. So, if the Product Owner doubts the quality of the definition of "Done", he/she can discuss it with the team on the next Sprint Retrospective, so that if they agree, it would be adjusted for the next Sprint.

column1: How long does the Sprint Planning take in a project with three-week Sprints?
Explanation: Sprint Planning is 8 hours for a one-month Sprint and usually shorter proportionally for shorter Sprints.

column1: Which Scrum artifacts are ordered?
Answer Option 3: Both the Product Backlog and Sprint Backlog
Explanation:
The Product Backlog is ordered (prioritized) based on the business value.

The items in the Sprint Backlog follow the same order they had in the Product Backlog, therefore, are prioritized.

column1: Which of the following describe the definition of "Done"? (choose 2 answers)
Answer Option 4: Helps ensure the Increment is releasable
Explanation: Definition of "Done" increases transparency because everyone knows what it means by "Done". It includes everything required for creating something usable by the end users (potentially releasable).

column1: Pick 4 activities that are the responsibility of the Development Team.
Answer Option 3: Break down epic user stories into smaller ones
Explanation: Designing the software is part of the development and should be done by the developers. They are self-organized and make technical decisions and volunteer for tasks (assign them to themselves). Estimation is the responsibility of the developers because they are the people who will develop the item.

column1: Which of the following is a valid service from the Scrum Master to the Product Owner?
Answer Option 1: Helping the Product Owner find techniques for managing the Product Backlog.
Answer Option 2: Act as a proxy when the Product Owner is not available to the team.
Answer Option 3: Helping the Product Owner order the Product Backlog items in order to maximize value.
Answer Option 4: Act as the middleman between the Product Owner and the Development Team, as requested or required

column1: When does inspection occur?
Answer Option 1: When the Product Owner finds necessary
Answer Option 2: Frequently, but not so often that gets in the way of work.
Explanation:
All Scrum events are opportunities for inspection and adaptation.

Inspection makes adaptation possible and that's why it's important. However, like anything else in Agile, we just like to have "enough" of it.

column1: When is it time for integrating the solution?
Answer Option 2: At the end of the Sprint
Answer Option 4: At the end of the project
Explanation: Integration is part of the development of each item and a step in a normal definition of "Done". Agile projects use continuous integration to make the output potentially releasable.

column1: Which role is responsible for managing the Development Team?
Explanation: The Development Team is self-organized and manages itself instead of receiving orders.

column1: The Sprint Backlog makes visible all of the work the ... identifies as necessary to meet the Sprint Goal.
Explanation:
This is up to the developers to identify how to accomplish the goal. After all, they are the technical people in the project.

The question is about the Sprint Backlog tasks, rather than items.

column1: It is forecasted that the project will be over in 4 Sprints. The Product Owner wants to design acceptance tests for all items. What's the best response from the Scrum Master?
Answer Option 1: It's a good idea, as long as the tests are not too detailed.
Answer Option 2: It's a good idea, as long as there's a similar set of acceptance tests for all items.
Answer Option 3: This is not necessary. The items should be discussed in more detail before development, rather than upfront.
Explanation: Scrum doesn't use upfront planning and design and what's described in this question is a form of upfront preparation.

column1: The Development Team is self-organized, and therefore, can decide to drop the Daily Scrums.
Explanation: The developers are self-organized and make decisions but only inside the borders set by Scrum. Scrum events should not be dropped.

column1: Which of the following is not improved by using timeboxed Sprints?
Answer Option 2: Prioritization of all aspects of work
Explanation: Technical debt is any shortcoming in the solution that makes it less than "good enough" and might create problems in the future. Refactoring is a common way of reducing technical debt. Timeboxing, however, doesn't help with technical debt. Timeboxing the Sprints forces everyone to focus on the most important parts of the work (prioritization). It also ensures there will be frequent increments which demonstrate progress. When working inside timeboxes, it's better to limit work-in-progress and get items done before going to the next ones; otherwise, chances would be high that the team ends up with many in-progress items and not enough "Done" items at the end of the Sprint.

column1: Time can be allocated between the two Sprints for integration.
Explanation: Integration is part of the definition of "Done" and should happen as part of the development during the Sprint. Each new Sprint starts immediately after the previous one; there's no time between the two.

column1: What happens to the incomplete Product Backlog items when the Sprint is over?
Answer Option 1: They won't be re-estimated, and they would be moved back to the Product Backlog.
Answer Option 2: They won't be re-estimated, and would be moved to the next Sprint Backlog.
Answer Option 3: They would be re-estimated and moved back to the Product Backlog.
Explanation: The items should be re-estimated because they have been partially done and the effort will have been changed as more has been learned. Whenever an item is not done during the Sprint (for cancellation or reaching the end of the timebox), it would be moved back to the Product Backlog, rather than the next Sprint Backlog. This is so, because the Product Owner might reorder them and they won't be on the top of the Product Backlog anymore.

column1: If there are 60 developers for a Scrum project, how should they be divided into teams?
Explanation: Each Scrum team can have a maximum of 9 members. When more developers are required, multiple teams can work on the same product and it will be called Scaled Scrum. The developers are self-organized and decide how to form the teams.

column1: A company has four products. Which two of the following are acceptable ways of forming Scrum teams?
Answer Option 1: There should be one Product Owner for each product
Answer Option 2: There can be a single Product Owner for all products
Answer Option 3: There should be a single Product Owner for all products
Answer Option 4: There can be one Product Owner for each product
Explanation: When there's one product, there should be only one Product Owner, even if the product is large and there are many Development Teams. However, when there are multiple products, there are two options: (a) consider them separate and have a Product Owner for each of them (b) have only one Product Owner for all of them and develop them like a larger project to ensure compatibility.

column1: Which of the following are optional in Scrum? (choose 2 answers)
Explanation: Velocity calculations and the use of burn-down charts are common and recommended but not mandatory. The rest are the Scrum artifacts. All Scrum roles, events and artifacts are mandatory.

column1: Which statement is correct about Product Backlog refinement?
Answer Option 1: It shouldn't consume more than 20% of the capacity of the Scrum Team
Answer Option 2: It shouldn't consume more than 10% of the capacity of the Development Team
Answer Option 3: It shouldn't consume more than 20% of the capacity of the Development Team
Answer Option 4: It shouldn't consume more than 10% of the capacity of the Scrum Team
Explanation: The 10% limit is only for the developers because their main responsibility is to develop the product and refinement shouldn't be a distraction for them. Refinement is one of the main responsibilities of the Product Owner and they usually spend a high percentage of their time on it.

column1: No one is allowed to participate in the Daily Scrum, but the developers.
Explanation: Anyone can "attend" the Daily Scrum but only the Development Team members are allowed to "participate".

column1: Which artifact contains a plan for realizing the Sprint Goal?
Explanation: The Sprint Backlog is the set of items selected from the Product Backlog and a number of tasks required for developing them and realizing the Sprint Goal.

column1: What happens to the Product Backlog when the end users' environment and needs change in the middle of the project?
Answer Option 1: There's no effect. If the changes are extreme, the project should be cancelled and a new one started with a new Product Backlog.
Answer Option 2: It evolves to reflect the changes
